element_texts.text:
January 1868
Here I am making good resolves. Only, I am afraid, to break them, but hope I may be enabled to spend this year more profitably than I did the last. 
Some days in the early part of this month have been very cold. the mercury going down to 28º and 30º below zero. 
Whenever the weather will permit the men are busy getting my house ready for occupancy. Our mails are received quite regularly now by the aid of Crow Indian couriers, but some foolish, irresponsible party at Fort Phillip Kearny having told the boys to hurry through, they not knowing but those were the authorized instructions, did so, surely killing one of the public horses they were

6
April 1868
Apr, 1st. Left Lt. C.F. Smith with 66 enlisted men of my company, and 7 wagons, for Ft. Phil Kearny. Took two loads potatoes and turnips. Genl. B. and other officers baggage &c. Genl Smith's train moved at the same time. Camped on "Muddy" - distance 27' miles. 
Aprl - 2nd. Moved before sunrise and camped on Willow Creek 22 miles. Maj Gordon expected to get out sooner than I, but I beat him, much to his chagrine. Met Dr Matthews with 3 wagons, and 20 men under Lt. Tillotson. Recd a small mail, by them. 
Aprl - 3rd Marched about 3 am, long long before sunrise and had made 8 miles before "Sol" made his appearance. Camped 4 miles above last crossing of Peno Creek. Distance 30 miles. The men keep up first rate and are anxious to beat the Cavalry, who went ahead yesterday, and took the new road, while I have chosen the longer and better one.

riding. This caused General Bradley to discharge them and employ an old mountaineer, Mr. Harwood by name, to carry the mails. 
Mr. Coover? of Gallatin Valley paid us a visit during March. He started down last fall in company with Mr. Bozeman, but was attacked by indians, and he wounded and Mr B killed. 
March 26th Genl. Smith and Lieutenant Bowman escorted by Maj Gordon's Co came up to see the Post and troops, some of us having never had the pleasure of meeting them. They seemed well pleased with the Post and condition of the garrison. Of course they visit the cañon, and the ladies going out we make it a little picknick party, taking lunch on the brink of the Cañon.

7

Cr. and camped on Tongue River. Saw fire at foot of the mountains. 8th nooned at Little Horn and camped on Muddy. Raining almost all day and very cold, and muddy.
April 9th Arrived at Fort C.F. Smith at noon, making the quickest trip ever made. Was not seen until we came around the point near the Post. 
April 10th. Three or four Sioux around. They fired a shot at a picket near the hay stacks. Found Lieut Thompson 13th Inf here having brought down Harley, Burke & a Phil. Kearney deserter. 
April 12th. - Dr. Matthews & Lieut Tillotson left for P.K. [?Jim?] Richard's outfit went along, intending to go to Laramie.
April 16th. Thirty Sioux made a dash on Zeuksburg's herd of mules. D. Co. was sent out to drive them away and protect the herd. Fired about one hundred rounds, and I guess saved the herd and perhaps some hair. Zeuksburg had one mule wounded so that he had to kill him. It is thought that Zeuksburg shot one of the indians
April 17th - Old Mr. Harwood the mail courier

I shot two chickens, one with gun and the other with revolver. Went after and shot at a band of ten elk. One of the men said I wounded one. Chased them along the road where Co. was marching 500 yds distance. Men poured in a volley killing two. Took hind quarters only.
April 4th - Moved from camp on Peno Cr. about daybreak.  Noticed the place of Shirley's fight.  It is the best place to make an attack that there is on the entire route.   Arrived at Phil. Kearney at noon, and would have arrived an hour and a half sooner had the wagons not broken down.   Saw a beaver in his dam.  The first time I ever had a chance of seeing one there, as they are generally very shy.  Met for the first time Capt Thompson, Lieuts Bonney, Connolly, Cole, Stemble, Paulus & Warren.
April 5th  Turned cold in the afternoon.

  "   6th  Had quite a snow storm this morning.  General Bradley and party left yesterday morning.

April 7th  Marched at day break.  nooned at Goose

8

H and D Cos. rushed out and with the mounted party followed 3 miles. Took one howitzer and fired two shells at them. One of the patrols is sure he shot an indian. Saw two others throw him across a horse and bear him away. On return found double barreled shotgun, bow, quiver and arrows, shield cover, whip etc etc. near where indian was when shot at 
April 30th = Maj. Burt called a meeting of officers last night as he understood that some of them differed with him in regard to the proper way of fighting these indians that come around, 
Concluded to take off the patrol and not follow indians so far if they did come around. Muster, Inspection and Review 
May 2nd Lieut Matson left with three wagons for Phil Kearney to bring up some medical supplies. Capt Wishart goes along as he expects Mrs. W. there by

came in with a mail. A thousand peacefull (?) Sioux were looked for at P.K. on the 16th.
April 18th There is not an indian - not even a pappoose, at the Post
April 19th, 20th & 21st  ----------------------------------------

 "  22nd Mail left. Per Mr. Harwood, at dark, expected back on the 27th.

April 23rd Cos are busy at target practice twice a day.
April 27th - Mail arrived at 11 am: learn that the Cheyennes who have been in at Phil Kearny told that the Sioux acknowledge the loss of one warrior and three ponies, died of wounds received in the engagement here on the 16th 
April 28th - Indians made a dash to capture the two men on patrol. E. Co. and the mounted party rushed out to the rescue and followed about 3 miles. Lt. McCarthy in command of latter is sure they shot one.
April 29th = Indians to number of 30 or more. again tried to capture patrol.

9

to trade and live in peace with the whites. The Major gave them some rations and put them in camp near the Fort. 
May 11th. The Cheyennes say there are three bands of Sioux on the Little Horn, but that none of them came here to fight during the last fights. They say they had not heard of the two last fights, but that a man was killed in the first one and one badly wounded in the 2nd. The Major issued 75 [?] rations to them. They say there are 170 of them here. They were not satisfied with the amount of sugar, so the Maj. gave them another sack. Should not have done that. Most of them left in the evening after trading about 200 robes with the sutler. About 150 Crows came in, in the forenoon and rations were issued to them. They say there are seven bands of Sioux on the Little Horn and that they are coming here to get revenge for the death of the chief killed in Aug. last.

the time they arrive
May 3rd Resting 
May 5th About 22 indians charged from the creek west of the Post, on the picket who was watching for the men working at the grave yard, but receiving a warm reception they moved down south of the fort on the run. D. Co. ran out and gave them a volley, and was then ordered to follow them a ways. Went about a mile with the usual success. A great many more came out of the creeks east of the fort, making the party larger than any that has been here yet. 
May 10th - Two Crow boys came in from their camp which is scattered from Beaubois down below the mouth of the Little Horn. Some more will be in tomorrow. In the afternoon quite an excitement was raised by the appearance of about one hundred Cheyennes, who came - they say

10

May 29th Mr. Story, McKenzie, Jim Leighton and Louis Richard came up in a couple of buggies. The two former are to be bidders at the sale. Mr. Story left Virginia City on the 8th inst., has been traveling through Salt Lake City, Cheyenne &c to Omaha & return and has during that time traveled 2600 miles. They left their escort of thirty men under Lieut Stephenson at Warren Creek but three of them had traveled from Laramie to Reno alone.
May 30th Lieut Stephenson came in. They saw three Sioux on Little Horn and two of the party out hunting had a little brush with them, after which one of them came in and had some coffee and bread.
May 31st. A farce of an inspection in barracks. 
June 1st The sale commenced by selling a box of tools to each Co.

May 13th Lieut Matson came back, but Capt Wishart did not come, having gone on to Cheyenne for his wife. Lieut Bonney was thrown from his horse while out riding when they were there and very severely injured. His life almost despaired of. 
Small mail and no news. 
May 15th was on duty last night. Night alarm, caused by sentinels firing at what they are sure were indians. They say they saw some one jump down from the east gate and run away. It was very dark. Tewksbury's men fired on some that they saw near his corral. 
May 27th Capt Thompson, Capt Wishart Capt D'Isay and Lieut Cole came up     Capt W. had got as far as Laramie when he received dispatches to return and attend to the sale of the Q.M. stores. Commencing on the 1st of June   This is a great disappointment as he had expected to meet his wife in a few days.

11

"Thin Belly" came in accompanied by a large number of women, who wait here until the Crows from Laramie who have not yet arrived come up. During the after noon the latter arrive and during the night of the 9th about 20 men under Thin Belly start for the Sioux Camp, to steal horses.
June 10th All the Crows leave for their camp and in the afternoon the two who went to steal horses came in with four as the result of the expedition. 
June 14th. Capt. Wishart arrives with Mrs W & the family. Bring mail and ordered for "D" and "I" Cos. to go to Fort Phil. K. I am loath to leave the place, as I have become quite attached to it. 
June 17th Did intend to start today but put it off until tomorrow
Dr Matthews came up with Capt

June 2nd Capt Thompson & Lt Stephenson left for Phil. Kearney at 5 a.m.
June 4th A man from Capt Thompson's Comp. came in about 4 PM with a note from Capt T. stating that he had lost all his mules and horses on Finch Creek. The man has suffered greatly and is scarcely rational and tells of seeing large villages of Sioux within 15 miles of this Post. Lieut Miller & G. Co. sent before dark, to take Capt. T to Phil. Kearney. Capt Wishant accompanies him.
June 7th Two Crows came from Village on way to steal horses from Sioux   Say main party of Sioux killed a Crow on the other side of the river. while he was returning from Laramie. Say a large party of Crows are coming to fight the Sioux in the morning. 
June 8th. About 50 warriors under

12

down to the road, and there had the men catch him. I could have caught him before getting to the train, but thought it would be fun to drive him in. Muzzled him to keep his noise from frightening the mules, and put him on the wagons, but when we next stoped found it had been muzzled so tight that he had smothered. Very sorry as I wanted to tame it. Dr. Matthews sent his interpreter out to talk to the indians after they had failed in their attempt, and they had the cheeck to ask why we had fired upon them.
June 20th Camped on East Tongue river. Indians in about the same numbers came about the same time for the herd, but again failed. They got into the brush and tried to shoot some of us and did fire quite a number

Wishart. and returns with us.
June 18th Made an early start and camp on Big Muddy. One indian seen. I feel quite boyish to get out in the green country among the trees again. All nature looks beautiful.
June 19th Camped on Trout Creek.
About 2½  P.M. about 30 Sioux tried to run off the herd, but as there was half a company on picket they met a warmer reception than they expected, and one dropped a double barreled shot gun, whether he was struck or not I don't know. While on the march I saw an old bear with her cub walking along near the road. Got a gun and gave chase, in which Dr. Matthews joined me. He had two fine shots at her but missed. Chased them until the old one abandoned the little one and then drove the little fellow

13

June 24th - Maj. Clarke the Paymaster arrived, bringing mail.
June 25. The Paymaster intends paying up to the 30th of April.
June 26th - Troops all paid and a good many men tight, including the 1st Sargts of "D" and "I", Cos. necessitating their confinement in the guard house.
June 27th - Maj Clarke left for Fort C.F. Smith.

     Lieut McCaullay with C. Co. left for Reno, as escort to large mule train hauling Q. M. Stores to Fort Steele. Lt McC goes as far as Fetterman. 

June 30th - Command mustered by Genl. Smith. Mail party left for East
July 1st - Major Gordon with D. Co. 2nd Cav. left for Laramie. That Co has been at this Post since Jan. 1867.

of balls into camp. Deployed skirmishers and advanced into the brush, when they vamoosed. Mr. Harwood, who had joined us yesterday started in to the Fort, before dark. 
June 21st - Camped on Peno Creek 14 miles from Phil. Kearney. Saw trail of war party and expected another attack, but it did not take place.
June 22nd - Arrived at Phil. Kearney about 10 a.m. Learned that Mr. Harwood had been chased by indians after leaving us the other night. Also heard the Lieuts Belden 2nd Cav. & McCaullay 27th Inf had had a very narrow escape from indians a few days before.
June 23rd - Courier arrived from Fort Reno, with the news of the death of Bvt Lt Col Smith Major of our Regt. He died yesterday afternoon.

who commanded the escort to that Post died there of inflamation of the bowels. He had been unwell for some time, and should not have left Fort Laramie on such a trip Lieut. S. brings his body along, intending to bury it at some of the permanent Posts or send it to his home
July 14th Troops paid for May and June.
July 15th Paymaster leaves for the states. Dr. Horton and Cody go along. They have been here since the establishment of this Post. This leaves me the oldest inhabitant. Lieut Bonney goes along have a Surgeons Certificate of disability.
July 16th Lieut McCaulley returned from Fetterman. He escorted a train from that place to Reno which was to take the Com. Stores from that Post. 
July 20th Richard's train arrived. They had some little trouble with

July 4th A very dull Fourth until about 6 P.M. when some 30 Sioux made their appearance on the Reno road, and seeing (I presume) that there was no stock out that they could take came down and wanted rations. The General would not have anything to do with them, and I think they were only watching a chance to kill some one. They were talking to some officers and some of the sutlers were outside stockade down at Mrs Barry's when the General ordered out Co. "I" and fired a volley into them that surprised them completely. I never before saw such scampering.
July 5th - A party of Sioux made their appearance on the hills other side "Piney" Genl. fired two shells at them which caused them to leave.
July 13th Major Clark arrived from Fort Smith. Escort under Command of Lieut Shurly. Lieut Neff 2nd Cav.

15

July 22nd Richard left for Fort C F Smith

 "   26th Mule Train arrived with mail
 "   28th  Train sent under Lt Stevenson & "A". Co. to Fort Smith.

July 29th - Train without mail arrived. Also Lieut S returned having met the courier from Fort Smith with information that a train from Montana had taken their surplus supplies and that they would leave the post on the 29th or 30th. Recd orders to proceed to Fort Reno with Co and take post - and assume command
July 30th marched at 530 a.m. and camped on Clear Creek. 16 miles Had a narrow escape by my horse stumbling and falling on my foot. Providencially I was I was preserved from any injury.
July 31st - Marched at 430 am arriving at Crazy Woman's Fork at 12 M. Remained until 6 P.M. and then made 9 miles by 8:30

the friendly indians. 27 chased Jno R. and two men from Browns Springs to Fetterman (30 miles) when they were trying to join Lt McCaullay's train. Some indians fired into McCaulley's train on Shell Creek 4 miles from this Post when they were coming in the other day and next evening a small party came down towards the Post "I" Co. sent out to drive them away.
July 21st Eight Sioux from Red Cloud's band came on the bluffs across the Piney and called Jno. Richard over. They said they had come to see if the whites had left the country yet. Said they were going to help them out. when they started.
"The White Forehead (Crow) came in from Fort Smith with dispatches in regard to abandoning stores at that Post.

over one day, as they had come from Fort Smith in 8 marching days and had laid over but one at Phil Kearney. The Genl met the ox train that I had sent to Capt. Hartz at Phil Kearney and turned back 19 wagons, thinking the remainder sufficient to re...? all the stores at that Post. and gave them to me to haul supplies from this Post.
Aug 11th Wallace & Morrison wagonmasters came with their trains of 34 wagons to move? this Post.
Aug 13t Captain Hartz arrived with cos C. I. & K leaving Stevenson behind with A Co. in charge of the bull train.
Aug 14th Capt. H. left for Fetterman
" 15th Stevenson left.
" 16th The wolves came up close to the stockade and killed my cat which was outside mousing. The sentinel heard the row but could do nothing to save poor puss.

And made a dry camp, taking water along for coffee for breakfast.
Aug 1st marched at 4am and arrived at Reno at 12m. Total distance 64 miles.assumed command of the Posts in the evening.
Aug 3rd Ox train of 75 wagons arrived. Think this will be enough to move everything from the District.
Aug 4th started train with 28 men for Fort Phil. Kearney. A few Indians seen about noon. 
Aug 6th Genl Smith accompanied by Cos.E. G. & H. arrived. Tendered the hospitalities of the Post to him within the best of my ability. Genl S & Lieut Bowman took dinner with us. 
Aug 7th Genl L. and command left for Fetterman early this morning. They were anxious to lie

17
and give the men water whenever they wanted it.
Aug 22nd Captain Hartz, who has been encamped here three days started, taking Stephenson (who has been here about 18 hours) along.
Aug 23rd Have great trouble in turning over the stores. Captain Atcheson? the A.A.qm being very unaccomodating. Several officers of the 4th call upon us. Bat Lt Col Carlton  Bat Capt Haseler & Quinn. & Limits Brown & ?
Aug 24th March at 3am, and camp at La Bonte creek - 23 miles. Dr Parry accompanies us being ordered to D. A. Russell and Dr McNeil goes as surg. of the detachment, being en route to New York to appear before the Retiring Board. A few indians seen.
Aug 25th Marched 23 miles camping on Horse shoe creek.

Aug 18th We moved early, thus finishing the abandonment of "the Powder River Country". Fired three shells and their explosion made up a salute of six guns. I was not sorry to leave that part of the country, but would just as ? stay at Fort Smith, as any place I ever was stationed. Marched to Dry Fork of Powder River. 17 miles.
Aug 19th Marched at 3am, camping on North Cheyenne near Wind River 25 miles.
Aug 20th. Camped north of Brown's springs distance 25 miles.
Aug 21st Marched 2.55 and arrived at Fort Fetterman about 1 PM distance 28 miles. The weather has been very warm, especially the past two. We brought the water wagon along, which was a great assistance to the men, enabling us to drive it up to the front of the train

Fort D. A Russell is a fine Post, judging from what I could see on a very short visit.
Aug 30th Met Mr Haymond, Mr Burrows & Mr Shirley. Genl. Smith relinquished command of the Regt to Genl. Bradley he being unwell and going home on sick leave.
Aug 31st Leave at 10am, for north Platte Co. C Lt McCaullay in same train bound for Plum Creek.
Sept 1st Arrive at north Platte and report by telegram to Maj. Howland commanding Ft McPherson & this district. Don't know whether I am to relieve Major Morris and his Co. of the 18th Inf. now here or not. Good barracks and quarters for one Co. and a very complete little Post. in every respect. There is a large R. R Machine shop, several stores, a large hotel and many more shops. Population of some 400 or 500. Mostly R.R. employees.

26th Aug - Marched at 3am. & camp on Laramie River about 30 miles above Fort Laramie, distance 26 miles. 
Aug 27th Camp on the Chug 22 miles saw the first horse - not connected with the army- that I have seen for more than two years and it was a ranch occupied by one man.
Aug 28th Camped on Bear Creek a small stream 3 miles north of Horse Creek. Met Mr Harwood who had for sale many vegetables unknown to us for a long time, distance 25 miles
Aug 29th Reached the camp of the 29th 1/2 mile north of Ft D.A. Russell early in the day - distance 27 miles - received an order immediately to proceed by rail to north Platte with my company. intend going day after tomorrow. Met many of the officers who have been away from the Regt. including Genl. Bradley, Col Haymond, Majs Burrows & Freeman, Capt Shirley & Lt Palmer,

Bradley came down by R.R and went into camp near the Post. I am still independent of any commander so there are three separate and distinct commands here.
Sept 10th - Genl Augur came up to see "Spotted Tail" and see about his transfer to the Reservation. Some 200 lodges of the Sioux will go.
Sept 11th - Ordered by Genl. Augur to report to Bat Major Morris for duty. The General returned to Omaha this evening.
Sept 13th - Lieut Warren? returned from Omaha where he had gone to draw clothing &c &c and brought an order from General Sherman transferring the Regiment to the Dept. of Missouri and ordering six Cos. of the Regt to march lightly to the ? waters of the Republican with 30 days rations and there scout until the rations are exhausted when they will go to Fort Wallace Rs on the line of the Southern Pacific R.R.

Sept 2nd Not hearing from Major Howland I reported by letter. Find the inhabitants in quite a scare caused by indian depredations along the Rail-Road. This is why I have been sent here. All the women and children staid in the machine shop two nights and the men still continue to do guard duty at night. Met and had a chat with General Harvey. He is here on duty connected with the removal of "Spotted Tail's" band of Sioux indians to their reservation. He is a very finely preserved old gentleman of the old school - must be 6.4 high, and is a very fine looking and active man yet.
Sept 4th Saw Genl Sherman en route from his trip to the mountains. He told "Spotted Tail" in my hearing that he must get out of the country along the Republican as that country would be full of troops within a month and they would not be able to tell the difference between friendly and hostile indians.
Sept 6th - Cos F. G. & I under Genl.

Sept 17th moved across the South Platte and go into camp. The men have been having a fearful drink and made last night hideous.
Sept 18th - Remained in camp all day completing the arrangements.
Sept 19th - Marched 27 miles to the North Fork of Medicine Creek. Country very poor. Nothing but low sand hills.
Sept 20th move about 500 guards to South Fork Medicine Cr.
Sept 21st March 17 miles to Red Willow Creek.
Sept 22nd March 12 miles to Blackwood Cr.
" 23rd March 10 miles to White Man's Fork and cross and camp on Palisade Creek near its mouth.
Sept 24th March 20 miles to Republican
" 25th March 23 miles point near the forks of the river and camp on South fork. See wagon trail leading from South up the north fork. Cavalry detachment learn they are a detachment of

Sept 14th - In compliance with a telegram from Genl Augur Major Morris sent me on the 12th inst. to the camp of "Spotted Tail", across the north Platte to count the lodges and estimate the number of people and warriors. Found the most of the men and many of the women drunk, and very noisy. Went to the lodge of Spotted Tail and had quite a talk with some of them. They seem loath to leave their old haunts, but acquiese in the wishes of the whites, and say they believe that they think good for them when they wish them to go north to their reservation. My Co. is one of those designated to accompany the expedition.
Sept 15th - Cos B. & K. from their stations up the RR arrive, making all the troops. Most of the officers have bought themselves ponies as Genl Bradley says they can ride.

three days but did not inflict any further loss, as they were well protected. They know of 8 indians killed and are sure they killed and wounded 70 of them. The squaws & children sat on the bluff urging them on to deeds of valor. Two of the scouts made their way out on the 2nd night and took the news to Fort Wallace. I forgot to say that the indians captured 7 horses and killed the remainder - 47 - But Lieut Col Carpenter 10th Cav. had arrived to their assistance on the 25th but did not consider his company sufficient escort to the wounded and was intending to send for further reinforcements. Col. Bankhead packed up everything and struck across the country for Wallace.
Sept 27th- Col. Brisbin returned and we lie in camp all day.
Sept 28th all return to mouth of

the 5th & 38th Inf and 10th Cav under Bat Col Bankhead 5th Inf going relieve Bat Col Forsyth of Genl Sheridan's staff who with some 50 Kansas scouts has been corraled for 8 days on the dry fork of the Republican. Orders from Genl. Sheridam to go to their relief. The cavalry sent at once.
Sept 26th We follow early in the morning and make 23 miles camping 2 miles below Arikare? fork of Republican and there some of the cavalry who return bring the following news. It was a party of 50 Kansas scouts under Col Forsyth who had been out looking for indians more than a month. On the 17th they were attacked by 500 or 600, and although  they fortified themselves by digging, they did not cover themselves until Lieutenant Beecher 3rd Inf (who was on duty with them) Dr Moore and three men had been killed & Col F and 17 men wounded. The indians fought them

to Beaver Creek and follow that up to the Fort Wallace Trail and from there back to Camp. The  Infty? are mounted in wagons. March 30 miles down the river camping at a place on the river called "Big Timbers". On the way the guide wounded an antelope. When "Tip" my dog chased him and caught and held it until the guide came up and finished it. It was the largest antelope I ever saw.
Oct 2nd - Marched 30 miles in a south east course to Beaver creek Ks. Saw plenty of fresh buffalo signs, but no buffalo.
Oct 3rd - Marched 23 miles up Beaver Creek crossing the south fork and traveling between the forks and camping on the south fork. We here struck the trail of the indians who fought Col Forsyth leading down the creek. It went about

river and camp on South Fork. Meet 4 couriers from Fort Wallace with duplicate dispatches for Genl B. with instructions from Genl. Sheridan to carry out Genl. Sherman's orders and then come in to Fort Wallace. He says the object of the expedition is to keep the indians from wintering on this river - to drive them south where Genl Tully? is operating with a strong force.
Sept 29th Lie in camp all day. Men on half rations of bacon. The cavalry killed one buffalo. I chased two the 26th but my mare was afraid of them and would not approach closer then 100 yds.
Sept 30th Move camp one mile on to Thickwood Creek.
Oct 1st Cos B & D and the Cav. all under Genl. Bradley start on a 5 day's scout intending to go down the river one day then strike south

an elevated plateau arriving at the camp late in the afternoon. Found that Col Mizner 2nd Cav had been out from McPherson and taken back all the surplus wagons, to bring out supplies for us. The news is that we remain here as long as Genl Sheridan wants us then go back to north Platte: that we are not to go to the Dept. Mo. Genl Sheridan having chosen the 3rd Cav. in preference. This news confirmed by the couriers who had arrived from Genl Sheridan. 
Oct 6th Laid in camp all day.
" 7th Moved camp about 5 miles up Thickwood Creek.
Oct blank space Co. went on hunting expedition, but did not kill anything. On return found Lieut Pealle? and Lieut Augur & unclear 2nd Cav. had come in with a train from Fort McPherson

two miles below where we encamped and then left the creek striking south. It was a very large one and I wish we could follow them, but we must follow the trail the wrong way and return to camp, not having been able to head off the indians as expected. The trail was not over 36 hours old at this point. Just as we were going into camp I shot a very large raccoon, gave him to the men and intend having a piece of him for lunch tomorrow.
Oct 4th - Marched 24 miles up the creek following the indian trail all the way - until we came to the Fort Wallace wagon road. See the fresh tracks of two or three mules going towards camp, which indicates that there have couriers passed lately.
Oct 5th Marched blank space miles over

creek which would seem to indicate that the indians were moving west of us. In the afternoon the wagonmaster and three teamsters went out to look for ponies, which had been reported in sight near the camp. They soon returned reporting the country full of indians, that they saw them coming from towards Beaver for as far as the eye could reach. Col Brisbin sent them out again to watch where they would encamp, and ordered D & K Cos to be in readiness to leave at once on their return and attack them.
About 8pm they returned ot having been able to see any indians or to make out what had misled them in the forenoon.

Oct blank space Major Freeman went with B. Co. to Fort Wallace for supplies, and returned on the blank space
Oct blank space Capt Mix? 2nd Cav went with his co. to Fort Wallace for supplies of corn. as the talk now is that we are to remain here until the middle of December.
Oct 29th Scouts came in bringing news of Genl. Carr having fought and dispersed the indians on Beaver Creek and that they were supposed to be moving northward Genl Sheridan requsts Genl B. to help in the good work of outing them off.
Oct 30th Genl Bradley with cos. F. I. & K 27th Inf & H 2nd Cav. started on a 5 days scout down the river.
Oct 31st Mustered by Maj. Freeman during the forenoon two ponies came in from towards Beaver.

25
Camped at point where the trail leaves the Republican. 31 miles 
Nov 5th - Marched to Blackwood 30 miles. Col Brisbin and Adjt. Bowman are passengers with us. The latter en route for Omaha to look after records of the Regt. 
Nov 6th Marched 27 miles camping on "North Fork of the Medicine".
Nov 7th Marched 30 miles camping on the Platte 3 miles below where the road leaves the bluffs. Rode out on the road, as I saw a man coming along in a wagon and asked him "what is the news". "Oh there are no news" said he. "What are the news from the states I asked". He looked at me a moment and then remarked "I am not from the states". As he was traveling westward with a load of wood I suppose he thought

Nov 1st - Capt Mix? returned. He saw a Co. of the 5th Cav. on Beaver Creek. Genl Carr was near with the other six Cos. They had been following the indians all over the country, and had struck them several times but had not had much of a fight.
Nov 2nd Pickels just above camp fired on what he said was a party of eight indians about 10pm.
Nov 3rd Genl Bradley returned not having seen any indians, but having seen plenty of small trails. He went some sixty miles down the river.
Nov 4th Co. together with B Co detailed as escort to train going to Fort McPherson for supplies. Left camp about 7am and

26
Maj. Howland, Col. Mizner, Capts. Moyes, Spaulding, Thurley & Lieuts Bates, Wheeling, Norton, Peale, Augur, Swigert Gregson? &c &c. Hear that Genl Grant has been elected without doubt, but cannot get the parties loss?, Hear that the indians from the Republican on their way north, tore up the R.R near Ogallala and threw a freight train off the track, killing one fireman. I understand Maj. Burt was absent from his command at the time.
Nov 9th Awaiting the arrival of stores.
Nov 10th Cat. Shirley started for New York, having been ordered before the Retiring Board. Lieut Bonney reported from leave of absence, and goes out with us.
Nov 11th Marched at 3 PM.

that I imagined he was just arriving from the states, a journey that is not made in wagons now. I then asked if he had not seen in the papers how the election went. He said he had not seen a newspaper for a week, but he "had heard them say that Grant had carried everything as far as heard from but he did not know how far that was. As he said he had gained this information some days before we didn't consider it very reliable. The mail was sent out to us from the Post and was very welcome. Recd. three letters from home.
Nov 8th - Marched 9 miles camping at Fort McPherson. Met a number of officers.

about the 1st part?. The indians having left the country, some going north and others south so Genl Bradley goes in on the 25th inst.
Nov 16th Capt. Ball & co. who had gone up to Thickwood to bring down the corn left there for want of transportation, came back.
Nov 17th Couriers for Genl Sheridan left.
Nov 18th - 25th Nothing to do but to keep ourselves warm and talk of the time of leaving, and count the nights yet to be spent in this dreary country.
Nov 26th Marched early with the other companies of the 27th (the two Cos. of Cavalry having been ordered on a scout up the river after making which they are to march to Fort Sedgwick).
The march today was very

Camping 5 miles west of the Post. We had about 2 inches of snow on the morning of the 9th inst. The first of the season.
Nov 12th Marched 34 miles camping on North Fork of Medicine Cr. Col. Brisbin who was to join us from North Platte did not get up until about 4AM next morn.
Nov 14th Marched 22 miles camping on White Man's fork. Here found Capt. Mix and co. having come over to conduct us to the new camp of the Regt. below Big Timbers.
Nov 15th Marched 15 miles arriving in camp about noon soon after couriers from Genl Sheridan came in bringing authority to leave so as to get to the Platte

we could see and after passing over a very rough road for a mile or so, got fairly started about 9 am, reaching "Medicine Creek in good season.
Nov 29th Marched before daylight, and reached the Platte about 2 PM. Genl Bradley thinking the troops would be so tired when they arrived here selected a camp at the nearest point that he could procure water, in consequence of which we were on short allowance of wood.
Received our mail, and lear from officers at the Post that Captain Hartz dies a few days before, up the Missouri, where he was with General Harvey.
Nov 30th Mustered at 9 am after which we marched to withing a couple miles of Fort McPherson, intending to cross

tiresome on the men. The snow being about 8 inches deep. Camped after marching about 15 miles, on "Palisade Creek," near where it empties into "White Man's Fork".
Nov 27th Marched early and lost some three hours in finding? white man's Fork, which was not frozen, but full of running slush ice. Put the men on the wagons. Of course all the mules had to stall here, and all the wagons to break, making it so late when we got fairly started, that Genl B. was afraid he could not make the 20 mile march to "Red Willow Creek." I tried to persuade him to do so, assuring him we could make it by dark. Camped on Red Willow, getting in just before dark.
Nov. 28th Marched as soon as

among others of Capt Louis Hamilton one of my Leavenworth acquaintances. Met Col. Townsend, the new Major. 
Dec 4-12 Snowing and blowing most of the time. There is about 2 feet snow on the ground and excellent sleighing. Have been to the city several times. My old Lieut Thomas of the 32nd came up to see me. He is in business in the city.
Dec 13th Received leave of absence for 20 days with permission to apply for an extension of forty.
Dec 15th Left on my leave at 11 am, crossing Missouri on ice.
Dec 16th Arrived at Chicago and saw Genl Bradley, Major Burt & Len Eget?, and Lt Murray?. Attended the Banquet in the evening where 1200 officers of the armies of the Tenn. Counterland

in the morning and take the cars for Omaha.
Dec 1st Cross the Platte ona. bridge and take the cars at 1 P.M.
Dec 2nd Arrived at Omaha after numerous delays at 4 P.M. Three hours behind time. After getting our stores unloaded and put on wagons for transportation to camp it was dark. Marched out to the barracks in a fearful snow storm, that commenced about dark, arriving about 10 P.M. As usual, no one knew the road out and we wandered around for a while, through the city. Found the quarters for officers would not be finished for some time. The new barracks are finished. Slept in 1st Sergt's room; Other officers sleeping in one of the barrack rooms.
Dec 3rd Hear of Genl Custer's victory over the indians, and death

pleasant chat with the former.
Dec 22nd Took a carriage and arrived at M's about noon.
Dec 28th Left for home, arriving in Pittsburgh morning 29th. While waiting for train in Harrisburgh, called on Gov. Gerry to ask him for one of Ed's pictures. Found him a very pleasant man.
Dec 30th Arrived home in the evening.
Dec 31st Annie Murray was married to Dr Samuel Hodgens?. Did not attend. So ends the Chapter.

Georgia & Ohio, sat down in the Board of Trade rooms. Saw many distinguished officers that I had never seen before, including Grant, Thomas and Schofield.
Dec 17th Took car for New York, going by Mich. Central through Detroit, Canada & Niagara Falls. Had a delay near Rochester, caused by accident to a freight train, so that we did not make connection, and did not arrived in New York until daylight of the 19th
Dec 20th Attended church at Mr Thompson's Church but he was not the preacher. Some irish gentleman filled his pulpit.
Dec 21st Left by way of Harrisburgh, there taking the Counterland Valley for Chamberstrong?. Saw McDowell and Capt Skinner old students, and had a
